title-group.article-title: Writing (Pre)History: Narrative and Archaeological Explanation in the New Guinea Highlands

abstract.p: The role of narrative in explanation has received considerable attention in most of the disciplines concerned with questions of historical process, including history, geology, psychoanalysis and palaeo-anthropology. Archaeologists, however, have been curiously reluctant to consider the proposition that their reconstructions of the past are fundamentally narrative in character. An argument is put forward for the serious study of narrative in archaeology, and three case studies from the prehistory of the New Guinea Highlands are presented in support: a brief review of the debate over the impact of sweet potato on Highland society; an analysis of the changing interpretations of the Kuk Swamp agricultural site by Jack Golson; and a summary of the role of indigenous narratives in accounting for the history of wetland drainage amongst Huli speakers in the Southern Highlands of Papua New Guinea.

Department of Geography, University of Papua New Guinea Occasional Paper No. 12. [Last section on archaeol- ogy written by Golson in 1974, after the May 1974 Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies conference to which he refers in 1977b.]

Golson, J. 1976a. 'Aspects of the agricultural history of the New Guinea Highlands.' In K. Wilson and R. M. Bourke (eds) 1975 Papua New Guinea Food Crops Conference Proceedings, pp. 79-80. Port Moresby: Department of Primary Industry. [Published abstract of a paper delivered at the 1975 conference.]

Golson, J. 1976b. 'Archaeology and agricultural history in the New Guinea Highlands.' In G. de G. Sieveking, I. H. Longworth and K. E. Wilson (eds) Problems in Economic and Social Archaeology, pp.20 1-20. London: Duckworth. [Written in 1973.]
Golson, J. 1976c. 'Archaeological investigations at Kuk Tea Research Station, Mount Hagen: an enquiry into the agricul- tural history of the New Guinea Highlands.' Unpublished report, 4 pp.

Golson, J. 1976d. 'The history of the sweet potato in the New Guinea Highlands.' Unpublished paper, 34 pp. [Written for Harry Maude's festschrift but withdrawn because of the considerations set out in Golson 1977c:54-5.]
Golson, J. 1976e. 'The last 10,000 years in the New Guinea Highlands and beyond.' Unpublished paper, 8 pp. [Revised version of 1977c]

Golson, J. and P. J. Hughes 1976. 'The appearance of plant and animal domestication in New Guinea.' In José Garanger (ed.) La Préhistoire Océanienne, pp.88-100. Paris: Centre de la Recherche Scientifique. [Written for, and published in, a pre-printed volume for a 1976 conference in Nice -thus probably drafted during late 1975 and early 1976.]

Golson, J. 1977a. 'No room at the top: agricultural intensifica- tion in the New Guinea Highlands.' In J. Allen, J. Golson and R. Jones (eds) Sunda and Sahul: prehistoric studies in Southeast Asia, Melanesia and Australia, pp. 601-38. London: Academic Press. [Written in 1975 for the 12th Pacific Science Congress, Vancouver, then rewritten for publication in 1976.]

Golson, J. 1977b. 'Simple tools and complex technology: agri- culture and agricultural implements in the New Guinea Highlands.' In R. V. S. Wright (ed.) Stone Tools as Cultural Markers: change, evolution and complexity, pp. 154-61. Canberra: Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies. [Written for AIAS conference in May 1974, revised for publication in first half of 1975.]

Golson, J. 1977c. 'The making of the New Guinea Highlands.' In J. H. Winslow (ed.) The Melanesian Environment: change and development, pp.45-56. Canberra: ANU Press. [Written in 1975 for the annual Waigani Seminar in May 1975. All but the addendum, which was added close to pub- lication, was rewritten during the first half of 1976. Not the same paper as 1 976e.]

Golson, J. 1977d. The Ladder of Social Evolution: archaeology and the bottom rungs. Sydney: Sydney University Press for The Australian Academy of the Humanities, 18 pp.. Also published in Australian Academy of the Humanities, Proceedings 7977:39-56. [Written in the first half of 1977.]
Golson, J. 1980. 'The Kuk Project.' Australian Quaternary Newsletter 15:13-8. [Republished as Golson 1980/81]
Golson J. and P. J. Hughes 1980. 'The appearance of plant and animal domestication in New Guinea.' Journal de la Société des Océanistes 36(69):294-303. [Unrevised version of 1976.]
Golson, J. 1980/1. 'The Kuk project during 1978 and 1979.' Research in Melanesia 5(1/2): 15-24. [Republication of Golson 1980.]

Golson, J. 1981a. 'Agriculture in New Guinea: the long view.' In D. Denoon and C. Snowden (eds) A Time to Plant and a Time to Uproot: a history of agriculture in Papua New Guinea, pp.33-42. Port Moresby: Institute of Papua New Guinea Studies. [Written as a single long article with 1981b and 1981c in early 1980, reflecting Golson's thoughts as set out in 1982b. Split into three papers by the editors.]

Golson, J. 1981b. 'Agricultural technology in New Guinea.' In D. Denoon and C. Snowden (eds) A Time to Plant and a Time to Uproot: a history of agriculture in Papua New Guinea, pp.43-54. Port Moresby: Institute of Papua New Guinea Studies. [See 1981a.]

Golson, J. 1981c. 'New Guinea agricultural history: a case study.' In D. Denoon and C. Snowden (eds) A Time to Plant and a Time to Uproot: a history of agriculture in Papua New Guinea, pp.55-64. Port Moresby: Institute of Papua New Guinea Studies. [See 1981a.]

Golson, J. 1982a. 'Kuk and the history of agriculture in the New Guinea Highlands.' In R.J. May and H. Nelson (eds) Melanesia: beyond diversity, vol 1:297-307. Canberra: Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University. [Written for the Annual School Seminar Series at the Australian National University, held in October/November 1980. Rewritten for publication in 1981, with reference to the volume edited by Andrew Strathern (see Golson 1982b) added later. Written in the light of 1982b.]

Golson, J. 1982b. 'The Ipomoean revolution revisited: society and the sweet potato in the Upper Wahgi Valley.' In A. Strathern (ed.) inequality in New Guinea Highlands Societies, pp. 109-36. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. [Initially prepared for a seminar given to the Anthropology Department at Cambridge in 1978, and then reworked over 1979 and 1980.]
Golson, J. 1983. 'Man in the Central Highlands.' Journal of Human Evolution 12(l):42-50. [Written during late 1981 and early 1982, in the light of 1982b.]

Golson, J. 1984. 'A proposal to proclaim a historic site at Kuk agricultural research station, Mount Hagen, Western Highlands Province.' Unpublished report, 10 pp. [A note in the Annual Report for 1983 of the Prehistory Department (Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University) states that this was submitted in 1983. Stems from correspondence in June and July 1982 initiated by the National Museum Director, Geoffrey Mosuwadoga which Philip Hughes and Golson then discussed with Western Highlands Provincial Government officials in October 1982.1

Golson, J. 1985. 'Agricultural origins in Southeast Asia: a view from the East.' In V. N. Misra and P. S. Bell wood (eds) Recent Advances in Indo-Pacific Prehistory: proceed- ings of the International Symposium held at Poona, December 19-21, 1978, pp.307-14. New Delhi: Oxford and IB H Publishing Company. [This paper was first written in 1980, although it was commissioned for the proceedings of the 1978 conference, at which Golson gave no paper. Published without significant revisions.]

Golson, J. and A. Steensberg 1985. The tools of agricultural intensification in the New Guinea Highlands.' In I. S. Farrington (ed.) Prehistoric Intensive Agriculture in the Tropics, Part 1:347-83. Oxford: BAR International Series 232. [Written early in 1984, after Golson abandoned the original paper delivered at the Canberra conference from which the volume was prepared in August 1981.]

Golson, J. 1989. The origins and development of New Guinea agriculture.' In D. R. Harris and G. C. Hillman (eds) Foraging and Farming: the evolution of plant exploitation, pp.678-87. London: Unwin Hyman. [Paper delivered at the World Archaeology Congress, Southampton, 1986, and published without significant revisions.]

Golson, J. 1990a. 'Kuk and the development of agriculture in New Guinea: retrospection and introspection.' In D. E. Yen and J. M. J. Mummery (eds) Pacific Production Systems: approaches to economic prehistory, pp. 139^7. Canberra: Department of Prehistory, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University. [Written in 1982 for the 11th IPPA Congress (part of the 15th Pacific Science Congress) at Dunedin in February 1983, submitted with minor revisions in 1983 and updated references just before publication]
Golson, J. and D. S. Gardner 1990. 'Agriculture and sociopo- litical organization in New Guinea Highlands prehistory.' Annual Review of Anthropology 19:395-417. [Written late in 1989.]

Golson, J. 1992a. 'Buhner Phase II: early agriculture in the New Guinea Highlands.' In A. Pawley (ed.) Man and a Half: essays in Pacific anthropology and ethnobiology in honour of Ralph Bulmer, pp.484-91. Auckland: Polynesian Society. [Written ("hurriedly" says Golson) in 1990, based on his First Mulvaney Lecture in Canberra in the same year.]

Golson, J. 1992b. 'Introduction: transitions to agriculture in Oceania.' Bulletin of the Indo-Pacific Association (1991) 11:48-53. [Written in 1992 as an introduction after the sub- mission of papers from the 1990 IPPA conference at Yogyakarta, Indonesia.]

Golson, J. 1992c. The New Guinea Highlands on the eve of agriculture.' Bulletin of the Indo-Pacific Association (1991) 11:82-91. [Written in first half of 1991, not originally deliv- ered at the 1990 IPPA conference at Yogyakarta, Indonesia.]

Bayliss-Smith, T.P. and J. Golson 1992a. 'Wetland agriculture in New Guinea Highlands prehistory.' In B. Coles (ed.) The Wetland Revolution in Prehistory: proceedings of a confer- ence held by The Prehistoric Society and WARP at the University of Exeter April 1991, pp.15-27. Exeter: WARP and The Prehistoric Society. [As for 1992b.]

Bayliss-Smith, T.P. and J. Golson 1992b. 'A Colocasian revo- lution in the New Guinea Highlands? Insights from Phase 4 at Kuk.' Archaeology in Oceania 27(1): 1-21. [Bayliss- Smith and Golson worked on the basic data in Canberra in April 1990. Bayliss-Smith wrote the framework of the arti- cle in August 1990 and Golson added his input late that year in the light of Golson and Gardner (1990), which had then appeared in print.]
